- Graphs are a data structure
to store relationships.

And so I think you can see
that there's a lot of potential

interaction and overlap
between gen AI and graphs.
And in particular, there's opportunities
for using graphs to help model context.
(upbeat music)

- Welcome to another episode
of "Data Strategy Unraveled."
I'm your host, Khendr'a Reid,

Principal Data Strategy
Tech Specialist here at AWS.

And today we're gonna
just be discussing Neptune
and generative AI.

And for those that are not
familiar with Amazon Neptune,
you may be wondering what is it,
how it can be leveraged.
We're gonna get into that.
And then those that do know Neptune,
you may be also wondering
how does a graph database actually

play a role when it
comes to generative AI?

So we're gonna discuss that
and more in today's episode.
And as always, I have a guest here
to really help us with this discussion.

And so I want to introduce
Brad. Hey Brad, how you doing?

- I'm doing great, Khendr'a,
thanks for having me.
- Hey, happy to have you here.
How about you tell us a little bit
about what you do here at AWS

and where you're joining
us from in the country?

- For sure. I'm joining you
today from Seattle, Washington.

There's a few of us Amazonians
out here in Seattle.
And I joined AWS almost eight years ago.
I previously ran and was a CEO of a small

open source graph database
company called BlazeGraph.
And then myself and a few

of my colleagues from
BlazeGraph joined AWS,
and a couple years later,

we launched what's now
called Amazon Neptune,

which is AWS's managed
graph database service.

Yeah, I'm also the General
Manager for Amazon TimeStream,
which is our time series database service.
- Okay. Okay.

So you are definitely the
guy we want to talk to today
about this topic here.

So how about first you
kick it off with what are

just some introductory
background information
on what exactly Amazon Neptune is?

- So graphs are a data structure
and graphs are awesome.
And the reason that graphs are awesome

is because they let customers
use the relationships

in their data to innovate
and make discoveries
and find things that you wouldn't be able

to find without looking
at the relationships.

And so graph applications
are any kinds of things

that you build where you're
traversing relationships,

asking queries that have
patterns of relationships,
and you're using those relationships

as first class citizens
In the graph data model.

One of the reasons that
graphs can be challenging
is because graph processing

is dominated by what we call
sort of random data access.

And so if you think about
how you and I are connected,

we might be connected
through another person.

And if I'm asking a
question that traverses
Brad's connected to Nicole
and Nicole's connected to Khendr'a,

the approaches that databases
typically use to optimize
that data access, they don't work well
because you never know,
it's hard to predict where in the data
you'll have that access.
And so for generalized graph processing,

purpose-built graph
databases can provide you
the best performance
to be able to build graph applications.
- Ah, okay. Okay.

So Neptune really provides
that capability there.

And so you mentioned about the
graph database capabilities,
but I believe also Neptune has a concept
of Amazon Neptune Analytics.

Can you tell us kind of
what the difference is there
when it comes to the analytics component?
- Yeah, so at re:Invent,
which is AWS's big annual conference
that I think a lot of you guys know,
we announced Amazon Neptune Analytics.

Amazon Neptune Analytics is
an analytics graph database

engine that does in-memory
graph processing.
And it's particularly good for use cases

where you need to load large
amounts of data quickly,
you need to run graph algorithms,
which are almost like little programs
that iterate over your graph.
And also to do very low latency queries
where you want to keep almost all
of your graph database in memory.

Neptune Database is our
other database engine

and it operates very much like
a traditional OLTP database.
So it separates storage and compute.

So you can store graphs
of up to 128 terabytes.

You can do high throughput
low latency graph applications
for selective kind of graph queries,
typically one to two hops.
And so we really feel like both

of those engines give
customers different options

depending on their use case
to build graph applications.
- Wow, all right.
So how does graph play a factor
or graph databases play a factor
when it comes to generative AI?
How do they intertwine there?

- Graphs and generative
AI have a lot of things
that are complimentary.
And one thing that if you think about
what generative AI, large language models,

foundational models do is
they use all of the things

that they're trained on
to help make predictions
about how things are related.
And we just talked about graphs

are a data structure
to store relationships.

And so I think you can see
that there's a lot of potential

interaction and overlap
between gen AI and graphs.
And in particular, there's opportunities
for using graphs to help model context.
And by that I mean you can use graphs,

and one of the classic
things that people do
with graphs is they build something
that can be called a knowledge graph.

It also has other names
where they use a graph
to represent things that you know,

so you might say something
like, Brad is a person,
Brad works at Amazon,

Brad is a General Manager
at a graph database service.
And you can capture things
and tell them explicitly what you know.
And this is also known
as explicit knowledge representation.

On the other hand, LLMs
can generate statements

and answers from things that
they've been trained on.

So they can take things
that they've been trained on
and produce other predictions about it.
And so sometimes you can combine

that explicit knowledge
about things that you know

with what LMS are producing
to give you better results,
produce generative AI applications faster,
reduce hallucinations.

And there's some really
exciting emerging work
in concept called graph RAG

where you can use
generative AI applications

for building
retrieval-augmented generation

and use graphs as part of
that to improve the precision

and the quality of the
responses that you're getting.

- So it sounds like
Neptune has a capability
of vector searches, right?
And so when would I want to really use
that vector search capability there?
- Yeah, so one of the first things
that customers often think about

with generative AI applications
is using vector search.
And vectors obviously are embeddings,

they can have a number
of different dimensions.

The type of foundational
model you use is really
what drives the dimensionality
and the types of the embeddings.

But what it allows you
to do is vector search,
sometimes also called semantic search,

allows you to find things that
may be related conceptually

or related through this
high dimensional projection
that an LLM or a foundational model does,

but you might not have
related it directly.
So it's an interesting way

to find things that are
related very quickly.
Now we think of the combination
of graphs and vector search,
we often call it vector-guided navigation.

And what the benefit of
using graphs in conjunction

with vector search is
that the graph allows you
to explain how things are related

that have been suggested
for by the vector search.
So think about vector

and graph as explainability
for similarity.
And an example might be,

so we have one of our
customers on Neptune Analytics
is a large book sales company,
and they have a challenge

that they wanna identify
books that are fraudulent
because the content has been AI generated.

So they weren't actually
produced by an author,
but they were AI generated

and someone listed them
on the marketplace.
Well what they do is they start

with traversing a graph
about the types of the books,
and then they take an embedding
that represents the aspects of that book,

and then they find things
that are similar to it
based on a vector search.

And then they go and look
at the information related

to the authors and people
who published that book.

And by combining that
with this graph traversal
about people who might

have been involved in a
suspicious transaction

or have some previous
history of known fraud,

they're able to use that
vector search to suggest things
and then use the graph to actually
narrow it down based on things
that we know have occurred
based on previous enforcement actions.

So it's a super cool example
of this kind of explainability

for similarity concept that
I talked about earlier.

- Yeah, yeah, I mean, I
feel like we already are
kind of on the bleeding edge
when it comes to generative AI in general,
but talking about this specific use case
that you just mentioned here, wow,
this is really next level here.

So how are other customers
leveraging these capabilities
today within Neptune?

- So across the Neptune
and Neptune database
on Neptune Analytics,

we've seen a huge amount of
interest in in graph and gen AI.
And it admittedly is very early,
like our customers,
we're really learning the best patterns

and the best things that
customers can use for.
Some of the traditional things that
are very popular graph use cases.

So those include fraud. We
talked a little bit about it.

Knowledge graphs as a
use case is very popular,
and it's really gotten a lot of attention
through the kind of the graph RAG pieces
that we talked about.
We have customers like NBC Universal
who are using basically a combination
of knowledge graph about different content
for their online television shows
with capturing social engagement.

And they use Neptune to perform
for those kinds of things.
We have a lot of interest in customers

in the financial space
for using combinations
of graph and vector search or graph

and retrieval-augmented
generation for sort of
the use cases fall in two categories.
One is improving research,
so helping to find things about companies
that might be non-obvious.

And then also this kind
of improving, you know,

know your customer kind of
compliance type of use cases.
So that's also a very interesting piece.
And then another area that we have a lot

of general graphic usage in
is the security use cases

and cloud security posture
management is one in particular.
Wiz, which is a large cloud security
posture management company,
and one of the fastest growing startups
over the last few years uses Neptune.
And they use it in a very interesting way,

which is they use it for
explainability of results.

And so I think we're
really interested to see
how customers like Wiz
and others will combine generative AI
with their security applications

where they're already using
graph for explainability
to really help innovate
and do new things for their customers.
- Yeah, yeah, and I can imagine a lot
of our viewers here are really interested
in some of those use cases as well.
And I can imagine they also are ready

to get started with
Neptune and how to use it.

So can you give us some
examples of the best ways
to get started with Neptune Analytics
or just Neptune in general?
- There's a couple of great ways.

If you're coming at it
from a gen AI angle,
Neptune has integrations with LangChain,

which is a popular library
for people to connect LLMs
and generate queries.

We also just recently
released an integration

with LlamaIndex, also a very
popular open source library
for people building RAG applications.

And you can do graph RAG
pieces with it as well.

So those are two great
ways to get started.
Use those open source libraries
and use the Neptune integrations.
We also have Neptune Notebooks.

The graph notebook is
something that we built
and released in open source

and it has a bunch of different
Python notebook examples
for different use cases.
So vector search, graph algorithms,

fraud, identity resolution,
knowledge graphs.

If you wanna get started
very quickly with Neptune
or another graph database for that matter,
you can download the graph notebooks
and those examples right there.

You can get them up and
running and then you can start

to tweak them and make them
your own from that perspective.

So those are fantastic ways
for customers to get started.

- Okay, thanks so much
Brad for joining us today

and providing us with
this wealth of information

on what Neptune is, how
it can be leveraged,

and some use cases actually
being implemented with it,
and how we can get started using it.
For all our viewers,

be sure to check the
description below to see

a lot of those examples
of how it can be leveraged
and how you can get started using it
within your own environment.

In addition to also
seeing more information
around just data strategy as well

as all the other "Data
Strategy Unraveled" videos
that we have published thus far.
And thanks again, Brad,
and thank you to our viewers for watching,
and we'll see you again soon in the next
"Data Strategy Unraveled" episode.
